title: (x) PMingLiU - light Times clone {Adriano S}
content:
I've got a logo that was developed using a Windows international font called PMingLiU. I'd like to find a comparable commercial font that matches exactly, but includes different weights and additional characters.   
   
Any suggestions?   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/24376.gif)
author: sperte

comments.content: I think [ITC Garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/garamond/lit/testdrive.html?s=The%20City%20Church&p=48) or maybe Storm's free [Lido](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/lido-stf/regular/testdrive.html?s=The%20City%20Church&p=48) could work there.

I don't think it's either of those. I've already tried the Garamond path, but the serifs on the T don't match. Good ideas though.   
   
Any others?

Oh sorry, I didn't notice that you were looking for exact matches.   
Could you post a larger image? That would help.
It looks like a lighter Times New Roman, slightly squooshed

This looks like a variant of Times. [Linotype's Times Eighteen](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/times-eighteen/) is very close, so is [Bitstream's Dutch 801](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/dutch-801/).   
   
Can I ask why 'exact' is needed? Except side-by-side, it would take an expert to notice the minor variations in the different Times versions, in my opinion.

Yes, it's a Chinese font.   
   
I was hoping to find a match that \*wasn't\* Times, but still retained the look. An exact match isn't necessary, except for my own satisfaction. I wanted to find a commercian font match that included different weights.   
   
I'll look into the Times family a little deeper. Thanks guys!
... I also wanted to stir clear from having to squoosh
Really, do give [Lido](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/lido-stf/) a spin, especially the condensed cut...plus, it's free!

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017014840im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/24389.gif)   
   
Close! It's a little too thick, and doesn't include the variations in weight that I'd expect.   
   
I may just have to settle for this though. It's a good font to use as default for Word, Publisher, etc. And you're right, the FREE price tag is a great sell point!   
   
S.
